messageBody:
> Jason Rogers :
>
> The point being to make sure that *YOU* write your tests so
> that they are
> independent of each other. If you write tests that effect
> data that other
> tests rely on, you will have issues. I don't know if that is
> your problem
> here, I just thought I'd "stir you up by way of remembrance."

> marko schulz:
> Problems might come up, if you are using some kind of singleton or
> global data. Other sources of of trouble include the use of mechanisms
> that do additional class loading, such as CORBA.

You need more information to pinpoint the problem. My best guess is that it
is about static variables combined with the classic classloader "problem".
If you have a class like this:

package org.foo;

public class StaticClass{
static int count=0;
public static void increment(){ count++; }
public static int getCount(){ return count;}
}

and a test method like this:

public void testStatic(){
org.foo.StaticClass.increment();
assertEquals("count not reset", 1, org.foo.StaticClass.getCount());
}

the test will always succeed the first time, and only the second time if the
StaticClass is reloaded. By default all classes in com.sun. sun. java.
(etc...) are not reloaded, therefore some libraries will retain state you
thought you did not retain (in particular when they implement singleton as
Marko pointed out).

Does your code use java.net, javax.rmi.CORBA, java.sql , ... ?
